title: Anthony Bourdain’s Personal Property Hits Auction
text:
Some of chef Anthony Bourdain's personal belongings will be auctioned online next month.

Text size

Some of Anthony Bourdain ’s most treasured items collected during his life will be auctioned online next month to raise funds for his namesake scholarship at the Culinary Institute of America, his alma mater.

The auction will be held by iGavel Auctions from Oct. 9-30, featuring 215 lots acquired by Bourdain, the celebrity chef, author, and travel documentarian who died of suicide in June 2018 at the age of 61. The items include artwork, books, home and decorative furnishings, knives, wristwatches, apparel, and more.

A significant portion of the proceeds from the sale will benefit the Anthony Bourdain Legacy Scholarship, which was established by The Culinary Institute of America in partnership with chefs Eric Ripert and José Andrés in June.

Custom Bob Kramer Steel and Meteorite Chefs Knife, with Certificate to Anthony Bourdain Courtesy of Lark Mason Associates

The remaining proceeds will go to Bourdain’s estate, according to Lark Mason Associates, which is handling the online auction.

“He was a larger-than-life personality with so many interests other than food, and this sale reflects his multidimensional persona,” says Mason, owner of Lark Mason Associates and iGavel Auctions.

An original typed manuscript or early draft for Bourdain’s 1995 novel Bone in the Throat has an estimate of between $700 and $1,000, and a script for the 2011 episode of The Simpsons titled The Food Wife, with signed inscriptions to Bourdain, is estimated to sell for between $800 and $1,200.

Other highlights include a Vietnamese blue-and-white ceramic tall bottle form vase, with an estimate of between $250 and $450; a Chrome duck press from the 2012 Paris episode of Bourdain’s Travel Channel series The Layover, with a high estimate of $300; and a custom Bob Kramer steel-and-meteorite chef's knife, with a high estimate of $6,000.

Chrome duck press from the 2012 Paris episode of The Layover Courtesy of Lark Mason Associates

“We have kept the estimates low,” Mason says, so everyone who loved Bourdain can have an opportunity to participate in the sale knowing that “part of the proceeds will be going to a good cause.”

The Anthony Bourdain Legacy Scholarship will support Culinary Institute of America students pursuing a semester abroad or taking part in one of the college’s global cuisines and cultures international programs.

The first of these scholarships will be awarded for the Spring 2020 semester, and the number and dollar amount will be determined later, as the school is continuing to identify other partnership opportunities and accepting donations through its website.

The scholarship is currently approaching $100,000 in donations, says Kevin Allan, the college's vice president of advancement. “We’ve seen enthusiastic response to the scholarship from friends and colleagues of Chef Bourdain, The Culinary Institute of America alumni, and the college’s supporters,” he says.

Bourdain graduated from the Culinary Institute of America in 1978.
description: Portions of proceeds from the sale will benefit his namesake scholarship at the Culinary Institute of America
